metadata.title: W3Schools.com

metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Git Config
Configure Git
Now let Git know who you are.
content.html: Now let Git know who you are.

content.text: This is important for version control systems, as each Git commit uses this information:
content.html: This is important for version control systems, as each Git commit uses this information:

content.text: Tip for Beginners: Configuring Git is safe.
content.html: Tip for Beginners: Configuring Git is safe.

content.text: You can change these settings at any time, they only affect how your name and email appear in your commits.
content.html: You can change these settings at any time, they only affect how your name and email appear in your commits.

content.text: User Name
Your name will be attached to your commits. Set it with:
content.html: Your name will be attached to your commits. Set it with:

content.code_html: git config --global user.name "Your Name"

content.text: Note: If you make a typo or mistake, just run the command again with the correct value.
content.html: Note: If you make a typo or mistake, just run the command again with the correct value.

content.text: The new setting will overwrite the old one.
content.html: The new setting will overwrite the old one.

content.text: Email Address
Your email is also attached to your commits. Set it with:
content.html: Your email is also attached to your commits. Set it with:

content.code_html: git config --global user.email "you@example.com"

content.text: Change the user name and email to your own.
content.html: Change the user name and email to your own.

content.text: You will probably also want to use this when registering to GitHub later on.
content.html: You will probably also want to use this when registering to GitHub later on.

content.text: Note: If you forget to set your name or email, Git will prompt you the first time you try to commit.
content.html: Note: If you forget to set your name or email, Git will prompt you the first time you try to commit.

content.text: You can always change these settings later, and previous commits will keep the old info.
content.html: You can always change these settings later, and previous commits will keep the old info.

content.text: Use --global to set the value for every repository on your computer.
content.html: Use --global to set the value for every repository on your computer.

content.text: Use --local (the default) to set it only for the current repository.
content.html: Use --local (the default) to set it only for the current repository.

content.text: Why Configure Git?
Git uses your name and email to label your commits.
content.html: Git uses your name and email to label your commits.

content.text: If you do not set these, Git will prompt you the first time you try to commit.
content.html: If you do not set these, Git will prompt you the first time you try to commit.

content.text: Now you have added the minimum of configuration needed to start using Git.
content.html: Now you have added the minimum of configuration needed to start using Git.

content.text: So feel free to continue with the next chapter.
content.html: So feel free to continue with the next chapter.

content.text: For more information about configuration, or if you want to change anything, keep reading this page.
content.html: For more information about configuration, or if you want to change anything, keep reading this page.

content.text: Viewing Your Configuration
You can see all your Git settings with:
content.html: You can see all your Git settings with:

content.code:
git
config --list
user.name=Your Name
user.email=you@example.com
core.editor=code --wait
alias.st=status
init.defaultbranch=main
...
content.code_html:
git config --list
user.name=Your Name
user.email=you@example.com
core.editor=code --wait
alias.st=status
init.defaultbranch=main
...

content.text: To view a specific value, use:
content.html: To view a specific value, use:

content.code_html:
git config user.name
Your Name

content.text: Changing or Unsetting Config Values
To change a value, just run the git config command again with the new value.
content.html: To change a value, just run the git config command again with the new value.

content.text: To remove a setting, use --unset :
content.html: To remove a setting, use --unset:

content.code_html: git config --global --unset code.editor

content.text: Default Branch Name
Set the default branch name for new repositories (for example, main instead of master ):
content.html: Set the default branch name for new repositories (for example, main instead of master):

content.code_html: git config --global init.defaultBranch main

content.text: Configuration Levels
There are three levels of configuration:
content.html: There are three levels of configuration:

content.text: The order of precedence is:
content.html: The order of precedence is:

content.text: The reason to use the different levels is that you can set different values for different users or repositories.
content.html: The reason to use the different levels is that you can set different values for different users or repositories.

content.text: This can be used for example to set different default branches for different repositories and users.
content.html: This can be used for example to set different default branches for different repositories and users.

content.code_html: git config user.name "Project Name"
git config --global user.name "Global Name"
git config --system user.name "System Name"
